awd_titl_txt: Computations in Stable and Unstable Equivariant Chromatic Homotopy
awd_abstract_narration:
The project addresses directly the heart of algebraic topology: computing invariants like numbers, groups, and rings to understand spaces. The goal of algebraic topology is to systematically build a connection between algebraic objects like numbers and geometric objects like spaces. This connection allows a two-way flow of information, with algebraic invariants distinguishing spaces and topological methods informing algebraic problems. Starting from foundational work of Quillen, algebraic and algebraic geometry data like formal groups gives rise to new invariants for spaces with striking properties. This project combines this classical thread with much more recent developments coming from equivariant algebraic topology. "Equivariant algebraic topology" remembers a collection of symmetries inherent in a space as part of the data, systematically grouping spaces with the same symmetries, and the numbers and invariants produced must reflect this. This extra structure provides more nuanced computations, giving more information about how the classically described invariants change under symmetries. Equivariant algebraic topology has experience a renaissance recently dues to the solution by the PI, Hopkins, and Ravenel to the Kervaire Invariant One problem, one of the oldest outstanding problems in algebraic topology. The solution introduced a host of new constructions and techniques that have striking ramifications in classical and equivariant algebraic topology, and the problems in this project focus on unpacking some of these new constructions and describing what they mean for algebraic topology in general. Many of the projects focus on diversity in STEM. The PI is currently developing tools to help others build a conference series for graduate students and develop their own conferences for younger researchers to attract them to a field. The PI is also in discussions with an HBCU about building more direct connections between their students and the PI's institutions, starting with electronic seminars to introduce students to active researchers in algebraic topology. The goal of these collaborations is to have more students from underrepresented groups enter and succeed in graduate programs in algebraic topology. Finally, the PI has developed and continues to refine a First Year seminar on "Women in Math."  The seminar connects students with female mathematicians, allowing the students the opportunity to hear about their research and experience.

Modern stable homotopy theory heavily utilizes the fact that the stable homotopy category behaves like a derived category of modules. The ground ring here is the sphere spectrum, and computing its homotopy groups is one of the overarching themes in the subject. The problem can be approached by first looking p-locally, and we can pass to the p-local stable homotopy category. Here algebraic geometry provides a further refinement via the theory of formal groups, a cornerstone of algebraic topology.  The current approach to understanding monochromatic homotopy is via certain homotopy fixed points computations. Computing the homotopy groups of fixed points and homotopy fixed points is very difficult in general. One of the most exciting new tools developed to solve the Kervaire problem is a general slice filtration, a method which directly computes homotopy groups of fixed points. For Real Landweber exact theories, this is an extremely efficient tool. For larger groups, computations are still tractable but much more mysterious. In all cases, many of the conceptual tools from non-equivariant homotopy are not available. Many of the techniques developed for stable equivariant homotopy can also be applied unstably. This gives a natural and geometric notion of "even" which refines the ordinary one non-equivariantly and which encompasses spaces related to Real bordism and its norms.  The PI expects to see a close connection between unstable even spaces, various orientations by norms of Real bordism, and Mackey functor objects in algebraic geometry.

por.por_cntn:
Loosely speaking, algebraic topology studies the ways one can attach invariants like numbers or groups to spaces in a way that allows us to distinguish spaces using intrinsic data. In the mid 20th century, algebraic topologist shifted focus to better understanding how these invariants themselves interact, starting with the development of "stable homotopy theory". This was an incredibly powerful shift, as it allowed tools from other disciplines like algebraic geometry to be imported and reinterpreted in algebraic topology, providing new intuition and creating new kinds of tools for distinguishing spaces.

Most spaces which arise naturally come equipped with sizeable groups of symmetries, and we can ask to include this as part of the data when we study these spaces. This is the heart of equivariant homotopy theory. Equivariant homotopy has experienced a renaissance in the last decade since its use by Hopkins, Ravenel, and the PI in the solution to the Kervaire invariant one problem. A key theme in the new approaches to equivariant homotopy is a more algebraic approach and a greater focus on subtle additive and multiplicative constructions possible in the equivariant world. In equivariant homotopy, there are many different notions of a "commutative" monoid, and these different notions of commutativity are parameterized by Blumberg and the PI's notion of an $N_{\infty}$ operad or ring spectrum. These form the right equivariant generalization of an ordinary $E_{\infty}$ operad, and much of the PI's recent work here has explored how to understand and work with these kinds of objects. In particular, much of the ordinary algebra familiar to researchers in homotopy theory or algebra had to be reworked to understand the impact of norm maps. The PI and Blumberg have explored the consequences of these generalizations in algebra and in stable homotopy.

Even additive questions in equivariant homotopy can be much more subtle than expected. In general, computing the homotopy groups of homotopy fixed points and their more rigid notion of honest fixed points is very difficult. One of the most exciting new tools developed to solve the Kervaire problem is a general form of Dugger's slice filtration, a method which directly computes homotopy groups of fixed points. Work of Hahn--Shi showed how the slice filtration can be readily understood for Hopkins--Miller spectra at the prime $2$ with their natural action of the cyclic group of order $2$. This ushered in a host of new computations with these spectra. Building on this, Beaudry, the PI, Shi, and Zeng produced new $G$-equivariant models of Lubin--Tate spectra at the prime $2$ for various finite groups $G$ that are well-adapted to using the slice machinery. This approach has also made more transparent connections between orientability of vector bundles for these theories and the structure of the Picard groups for their fixed points, as shown in work of Beaudry, Bobkova, the PI, and Stojanoska.

The PI has also been very active in community-building in algebraic topology and in mathematics in general. Over the duration of the grant, the PI organized a series of conferences around the US and abroad. Care was taken to ensure the participation of early career researchers and of people in algebraic topology from traditionally excluded groups. The PI gave a series of talks aimed at early career researchers in the field at the Young Topologists Conference in Copenhagen and at the Graduate Student Topology and Geometry Conference, and the PI gave  the Hayden--Howard Lecture at the University of Kentucky aimed at a general mathematical audience.

Additionally, the PI cofounded "Spectra: the organization for LGBT mathematicians", an international organization for LGBTQ+ mathematicians and their allies. This organization has organized several panel discussions at the Joint Mathematics Meetings, and each year, it organizes an LGBTQ+ social gathering at the JMM. The past several years have seen tremendous growth in Spectra, starting with the creation of the Out and Ally lists and continuing through formalization of the board and structure. The PI has also been active pushing mathematics publishers adopt more trans inclusive naming practices.
